case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal v. Bhopal Textiles Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 755 of 1957 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 755 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 23, 1955,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated March 23, 1955 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 240 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 23, 1955, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 240 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 17, 1960 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. October, 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by. HIDAYATULLAH J.-This appeal, with special leave,

facts.text: Reference under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 by Nagpur High Court.

anchor.surface_text: judgment of the Nagpur High Court in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, by which the High Court answered the following question

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: by which the High Court answered the following question in the negative Whether the proportionate profits on the goods of the value of Rs. 4,10,785 were received

facts.text: Appellant is Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal is the appellant, and the Bhopal Textiles Ltd., Bhopal, is the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent is Bhopal Textiles Ltd., Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal is the appellant, and the Bhopal Textiles Ltd., Bhopal, is the respondent.

facts.text: Assessment year 1944-45.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1944-45, the Company which was number-resident was treated as resident and ordinarily resident under s. 4 1  c  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Company was non-resident but treated as resident and ordinarily resident under s. 4(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1944-45, the Company which was number-resident was treated as resident and ordinarily resident under s. 4 1  c  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Company supplied manufactured articles to Government of India or its nominees at Agra, Allahabad and Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account, it had supplied its manufactured articles either to the Government of India or its numberinees at Agra, Allahabad and Delhi.

facts.text: Goods sent direct to nominated persons who made payment against the goods.

anchor.surface_text: Under the orders of the Government, the goods were sent direct to the persons numberinated, who made the payment against the goods.

facts.text: Goods sent from Bhopal, railway freight and other charges borne by buyers.

anchor.surface_text: The goods were all sent for Bhopal, and the railway freight and other charges were to be borne by the buyers to whom the railway receipts made out

facts.text: Railway receipts made out in name of company consignees sent by Company through Imperial Bank at Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: to whom the railway receipts made out in the name of the companysignees were sent by the Company through the Imperial Bank at Bhopal.

facts.text: Bhopal Branch sent railway receipts to Bank branches at Agra, Allahabad and Delhi which collected amounts from buyers and transmitted to Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The Bhopal Branch sent the railway receipts to branches of the Bank at Agra, Allahabad and Delhi, which companylected the amounts due from the buyers, and transmitted them to the Imperial Bank, Bhopal,

facts.text: Department held total sum of Rs. 4,40,373 received in British India.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, a total sum of Rs. 4,40,373 was held by the Department to have been received in British India.

facts.text: Rs. 29,588 representing receipts for supplies direct to Government no longer in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: of that sum, an amount of Rs. 29,588 which represented the receipts for supplies direct to Government is numberlonger in dispute.

facts.text: Balance Rs. 4,10,785 was subject-matter of the reference.

anchor.surface_text: The balance represents the sum, which was the subject-matter of the reference.

facts.text: Tribunal did not accept company's contention that money not received in British India.

anchor.surface_text: The usual appeals followed, and the companytention of the Company that the money was number received in, British India was number accepted by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal did not decide place of accrual.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal did number decide about the place of accrual.

facts.text: High Court held property in goods passed to buyers, Imperial Bank received as agents of buyers.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court in deciding the reference went into the question of passing of property under the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930, and came to the companyclusion that since the property in the goods had passed to the buyers, the Imperial Bank of India, Bhopal, must be deemed to have received the railway receipts as agents of the buyers .

facts.text: Supreme Court holds income received at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi by Imperial Bank as agent of Company.

anchor.surface_text: Coming number to the question as to where the amount was received, we have numberdoubt that the view of the Tribunal was companyrect. This income was received at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi from the buyers by the Imperial Bank acting as the agent of the Company.

facts.text: Railway receipt is a document of title to goods.

anchor.surface_text: A railway receipt is a document of title to goods, and, for all purposes, represents the goods.

facts.text: Company handed over railway receipt to Bank with covering letter to deliver against payment.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence- and has been adverted to by the Incometax Officer-that the Company, when it handed over the railway receipt to the Imperial Bank at Bhopal, did so along with a companyering letter in which it asked the Bank to deliver the railway receipt and the bill to the buyers against payment of the bill amount plus companylection charges.

facts.text: Bhopal was outside taxable territories at material time.

anchor.surface_text: or in Bhopal, which was then outside the taxable territories.

issues.text: Whether the proportionate profits on the goods of the value of Rs. 4,10,785 were received or were deemed to be received in British India, in the year of account, by or on behalf of the assessee Company within the meaning of Section 4 1  a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: Whether the proportionate profits on the goods of the value of Rs. 4,10,785 were received or were deemed to be received in British India, in the year of account, by or on behalf of the assessee Company within the meaning of Section 4 1  a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 .

issues.text: the question as to where the amount was received

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the question as to where the amount was received, we have no doubt that the

issues.text: whether property in the goods could be said to have passed absolutely to the buyers without any right of disposal being reserved by the Company

anchor.surface_text: We need not, therefore, concern ourselves with the problem whether property in the goods could be said to have passed absolutely to the buyers without any right of disposal being reserved by the Company.

issues.text: whether the case is distinguishable on the ground that the railway receipts there were to self whereas here the railway receipts were made out in the name of the consignee

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Veda Vyasa contends that the case is distinguishable on the ground that the railway receipts there were to self whereas here the railway receipts, were made out in the name of the consignee.

arguments.claim: The money was not received in British India

anchor.surface_text: The usual appeals followed, and the contention of the Company that the money was not received in, British India was not accepted by the Tribunal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ourt. Since we are number deciding the question of accrual, we do number elaborate the point. Coming number to the question as to where the amount was

arguments.court_reasoning: Income received by agent (Imperial Bank) at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi

arguments.claim: Total sum of Rs. 4,40,373 was received in British India

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, a total sum of Rs. 4,40,373 was held by the Department to have been received in British India.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ourt. Since we are number deciding the question of accrual, we do number elaborate the point. Coming number to the question as to where the amount was

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirms Tribunal's view that income received at Agra etc. by agent

arguments.claim: Profits not received in British India because property passed to buyers and Imperial Bank received railway receipts as agents of buyers; branches at Agra etc. agents of buyers; received only at Bhopal

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in deciding the reference went into the question of passing of property under the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930, and came to the conclusion that since the property in the goods had passed to the buyers, the Imperial Bank of India, Bhopal, must be deemed to have received the railway receipts as agents of the buyers . Continuing the reason, the learned Judges observed So also the branches of the Bank at Agra, Allahabad and Delhi acted as the agents of the buyers when they collected the money from them and transmitted it to the Bhopal branch. In this view, the profits cannot be said to be received by the assessee Company in British India.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: receipt and the bill to the buyers against payment of the bill amount plus companylection charges. In this view of the matter, though we do number ex

arguments.court_reasoning: Doubts property passed; right of disposal reserved; railway receipt document of title not handed over till payment

arguments.claim: Railway receipt is a document of title to goods, represents the goods; property transfers on handing over to consignee on payment

anchor.surface_text: A railway receipt is a document of title to goods, and, for all purposes, represents the goods. When the railway receipt is handed over to the consignee on payment, the property in the goods is transferred.

arguments.claim: Property in goods did not pass absolutely to buyers without right of disposal reserved by Company; doubt whether right of disposal parted with

anchor.surface_text: The case was not decided by the Tribunal on the basis of accrual of the income, profits or gains to the Company. It was decided on the fact of actual receipt, whether it was in British India or in Bhopal, which was then outside the taxable territories. We need not, therefore, concern ourselves with the problem whether property in the goods could be said to have passed absolutely to the buyers without any right of disposal being reserved by the Company. It is a matter of some doubt whether the goods were absolutely at the disposal of the buyers after the railway receipts were handed over to the Bank.

arguments.qualifiers: matter of some doubt; do not express any final opinion

arguments.claim: Company handed over railway receipt with covering letter to deliver against payment, so right of disposal reserved

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence- and has been adverted to by the Income-tax Officer-that the Company, when it handed over the railway receipt to the Imperial Bank at Bhopal, did so along with a covering letter in which it asked the Bank to deliver the railway receipt and the bill to the buyers against payment of the bill amount plus collection charges.

arguments.claim: Income received at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi by Imperial Bank as agent of Company

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the question as to where the amount was received, we have no doubt that the view of the Tribunal was correct. This income was received at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi from the buyers by the Imperial Bank acting as the agent of the Company. The Company had handed over the railway receipts to the Bank, and asked the Bank not to hand over the railway receipts to the buyers, unless payment was received.

arguments.claim: Instructions to Bank not to hand over documents unless payment received makes Bank agent of Company; buyers could not countermand

anchor.surface_text: This was sufficient to make the Bank an agent of the Company. The buyers could not have countermanded the instructions given by the Company to the Bank, which they would, indubitably, have been able to do, if the Bank was their agent.

arguments.claim: P.M. Rathod case applies; laid down that Bank is agent of seller

anchor.surface_text: This was laid down by this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax v. P. M. Rathod and Company 1 .

arguments.claim: Rathod case not distinguishable because railway receipts to self vs to consignee; document of title still property of Company till payment and handover

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Veda Vyasa contends that the case is distinguishable on the ground that the railway receipts there were to self whereas here the railway receipts, were made out in the name of the consignee. Nothing turns upon this distinction. The document of title to goods was still the property of the Company till payment for it was received and it was handed over.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , indubitably, have been able to do, if the Bank was their agent. This was laid down by this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax v. P. M. Rathod a

arguments.court_reasoning: Nothing turns upon this distinction; document of title remained property of Company till payment

arguments.claim: Agreement provided goods and price at Bhopal; handover to Bank at Bhopal in furtherance; money handed over at Bhopal; thus received at Bhopal

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Veda Vyasa finally contended that the agreement between the parties was that the goods were to be sent for Bhopal, and that the price was also to be paid there. He contended that the handing over of the railway receipts to the Bank at Bhopal was in furtherance of the agreement, that the money was ultimately obtained by the Bank and handed over at Bhopal also, and that, thus, the money must be deemed to have been received there.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ded that the agreement between the parties was that the goods were to  1  1960 1 S.C.R. 401. be sent for Bhopal, and that the price was also to be pai

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreement departed from; ordinary mercantile practice followed; payment to agent determines place of receipt

arguments.claim: View of Tribunal was correct that income received in British India

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the question as to where the amount was received, we have no doubt that the view of the Tribunal was correct.

holdings.text: we have no doubt that the view of the Tribunal was correct. This income was received at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi from the buyers by the Imperial Bank acting as the agent of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the question as to where the amount was received, we have no doubt that the view of the Tribunal was correct. This income was received at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi from the buyers by the Imperial Bank acting as the agent of the Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Company handed over railway receipts to bank with instructions not to deliver unless payment received; confirms Tribunal view on place of receipt.

holdings.text: This was sufficient to make the Bank an agent of the Company. The buyers could not have countermanded the instructions given by the Company to the Bank, which they would, indubitably, have been able to do, if the Bank was their agent.

anchor.surface_text: This was sufficient to make the Bank an agent of the Company. The buyers could not have countermanded the instructions given by the Company to the Bank, which they would, indubitably, have been able to do, if the Bank was their agent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Instructions from company to bank created agency; buyers lacked power to countermand, distinguishing from buyer agency.

holdings.text: This was laid down by this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax v. P. M. Rathod and Company. In this view of the matter, we are of opinion that the ruling in question applies.

anchor.surface_text: This was laid down by this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax v. P. M. Rathod and Company. Mr. Veda Vyasa contends that the case is distinguishable on the ground that the railway receipts there were to self whereas here the railway receipts,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior Supreme Court ruling on bank as seller's agent directly applies to facts.

holdings.text: Nothing turns upon this distinction. The document of title to goods was still the property of the Company till payment for it was received and it was handed over.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing turns upon this distinction. The document of title to goods was still the property of the Company till payment for it was received and it was handed over. In this view of the matter, we are of opinion that the ruling in question app-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Railway receipt endorsement to consignee does not alter control or agency; remains company's property until payment and handover.

holdings.text: the fact of payment to the agent determines the place where the money can be said to be received by the Company. That place was at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: the ordinary mercantile practice of handing over the railway receipts to ones own bankers with a request to hand over the receipts against payment to the buyers was followed. The Bank, as we have shown above, was thus the agent of the sellers,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement terms departed from in practice; payment location to seller's agent fixes place of receipt under mercantile practice.

holdings.text: In this view, the income, profits or gains must be deemed to have been received in the taxable territories, and the answer to the question ought to have been in the affirmative. We accordingly allow the appeal, and answer the question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: the fact of payment to the agent determines the place where the money can be said to be received by the Company. That place was at Agra, Allahabad or Delhi. In this view, the income, profits or gains must be deemed to have been received in the taxable territories,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of agency, document title, and precedent leads to affirmative answer on receipt in British India.

holdings.text: A railway receipt is a document of title to goods, and, for all purposes, represents the goods.

anchor.surface_text: A railway receipt is a document of title to goods, and, for all purposes, represents the goods. When the railway receipt is handed over to the consignee on payment, the property in the goods is transferred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General legal principle applied to facts of transaction.

holdings.text: though we do not express any final opinion, we doubt whether the right of disposal was parted with by the Company.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence- and has been adverted to by the Income-tax Officer-that the Company, when it handed over the railway receipt to the Imperial Bank at Bhopal, did so along with a covering letter in which it asked the Bank to deliver the railway receipt and the bill to the buyers against payment of the bill amount plus collection charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Covering letter reserved right of disposal; doubts High Court finding on property passing but declines to decide.
